title: Model A Discrete Random Variable
text: We would like to model a discrete random variable (rv) that is distributed by a non-standard probability distribution.

title: Model A Discrete Random Variable
text:
Solution
We model it using SciPy’s rv_discrete class.

title: Model A Discrete Random Variable
text:
Example
Let \(X\) be a discrete rv that has the p.m.f.



\(x\)
0
1
2
3
4




\(p(x)\)
0.1
0.2
0.4
0.2
0.1



Import the depedencies.

from scipy import stats as st

To initialise an instance of rv_discrete, we require both the event space and the probability associated with each event.
Let xk and pk be the event space and probability of each event, such that for P(xk[i]) = pk[i], i ∈ [0, 1, 2, 3, 4].

xk = tuple([*range(5)])
pk = tuple([0.1, 0.2, 0.4, 0.2, 0.1])

Initialise rv, an instance rv_discrete, passing (xk, pk) as an actual argument for the values parameter.

rv = st.rv_discrete(values=(xk, pk))

title: Model A Continuous Random Variable
text: We would like to model a continuous random variable (rv) that is distributed by a non-standard probability distribution.

title: Model A Continuous Random Variable
text:
Solution
We model it using SciPy’s rv_continuous class.

title: Model A Continuous Random Variable
text:
Example
Let \(T\) be a continuous rv that has p.d.f.,
\[
f(t) = \frac{t}{48}, \enspace 2 \le t \le 10.
\]
Import the dependencies.

from scipy import stats as st

Declare a new subclass of rv_continuous, and override the _pdf method.






Note



We override the constructor here because the \(T\) is bounded.
If it was unbounded, then we do not need to override the constructor.



class t_gen(st.rv_continuous):
    def __init__(self):
        super().__init__(a=2, b=10)

    def _pdf(self, t):
        return t / 48

Initialise t, an instance t_gen.

t = t_gen()
